title: Molar volume and condensation to liquid

content.question: The gases <math alttext="C O 2, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></math> and <math alttext="N H 3, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> can be liquefied at <math alttext="20 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>20</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> by compressing them to sufficiently high pressures. A student claims that <math alttext="N H 3, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> can be liquefied at a lower pressure than <math alttext="C O 2, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></math> can be liquefied. Which of the following is the best justification for this claim?

choices.label: At <math alttext="20 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>20</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, the average speed of <math alttext="N H 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> molecules is greater than that of <math alttext="C O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> molecules because <math alttext="N H 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> molecules have less mass than <math alttext="C O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> molecules have.

<math alttext="C O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> is a nonpolar molecule that has no significant intermolecular forces, whereas <math alttext="N H 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> has strong London dispersion intermolecular forces.

Both <math alttext="C O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> and <math alttext="N H 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> are nonpolar molecules that have only London dispersion intermolecular forces, but the larger electron cloud of <math alttext="C O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> molecules causes it to have stronger intermolecular forces.

<math alttext="C O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> is a nonpolar molecule that has London dispersion intermolecular forces that are weaker than the dipole-dipole and London dispersion forces between the polar <math alttext="N H 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> molecules.

content.answer: <math alttext="C O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> is a nonpolar molecule that has London dispersion intermolecular forces that are weaker than the dipole-dipole and London dispersion forces between the polar <math alttext="N H 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> molecules.

skill.text: 6.E: Provide reasoning to justify a claim using connections between particulate and macroscopic scales or levels.
